newsitem.title: UK: UK post unions warned by management before strike.
newsitem.headline: UK post unions warned by management before strike.

text.p: British post office unions were warned by management on Wednesday that jobs could be at risk if the Royal Mail's monopoly on letter delivery was suspended for a further three months because of strike.
Mail workers belonging to the Communications Workers Union (CWU) are to stage a 24-hour strike on Thursday, the latest in a series of stoppages over proposed new working arrangements.
The government suspended the Royal Mail's monopoly from August 6 because of the disruption caused by the strikes, and threatened a three-month extension if the stoppages continued.
Post Office Chief Executive John Roberts summoned leaders of the CWU and other postal unions to a meeting to spell out what this would mean.

"Any squeeze on our business inevitably means a squeeze on our costs. In a business where 65 percent of our costs are people costs, jobs will be a major focus of attention," he told them, according to a statement issued by the Post Office.
He again called on the CWU to ballot its members on the new working arrangements, which had been accepted the union's negotiators but then rejected by its executive.
The CWU wants further talks. The Post Office said there was no discussion at Wednesday's meeting of the issues behind the dispute.
